feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It divides an employee's total salary (basic plus allowances) by the actual number of working or calendar days in the month to determine the per-day pay rate. Public holidays are explicitly deducted from working day counts to ensure accurate calculations. The calculated daily pay is then used to generate automatic pay deductions reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests. This feature ensures consistent and compliant salary deductions across the organization's leave management process.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article documents how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It explains that daily pay is derived by dividing an employee's total salary (basic plus allowances) by the number of actual working days in the month. The article specifies that organizations can use either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days) based on their leave policy. Crucially, public holidays falling within the month must be deducted from the working day count to calculate actual working days. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction associated with that request is created and reflected on the payroll table using the calculated daily pay rate.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature as a flexible alternative to previous fixed calculation methods. Explains three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), three salary component options, and three main payroll impacts (salary proration, leave encashment, unpaid leave deduction). Provides definitions and use cases, particularly for UAE/KSA labor law compliance using 30-day custom months. Specifies access path as Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation and identifies user roles (Superadmin, Payroll table managers, transaction processors).

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). It covers the navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), the impact on active payroll transactions, and the requirement to reject existing prorated salary transactions when the payroll month is open before saving new proration settings.

job_to_be_done.statement: Calculate and deduct daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave by determining the appropriate salary reduction based on the number of actual working or calendar days in the month, accounting for public holidays.

Provide a flexible and customizable method for calculating daily wages to determine salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction amounts with greater control than previously available fixed calculation options.

Adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days).

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction must be calculated and applied to the employee's payroll.
steps: Receive and approve the unpaid leave request
Identify the leave policy type (calendar days or working days)
Determine the total number of days in the leave policy (e.g., 22 working days or 30 calendar days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the calculation month
Subtract public holidays from the total day count to arrive at actual working days
Obtain the employee's total salary (Basic + Allowance)
Divide total salary by actual working days to calculate daily pay
Automatically generate and reflect the pay deduction on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying daily wage calculation methodology for payroll processing.
steps: Navigate to Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
System applies selected configuration to salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked, or to adjust calculation methodology for ongoing payroll
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject the existing transactions before saving new proration settings
Confirm new proration settings are applied

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay calculation formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month. ; The leave policy can be based on either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 working days); the calculation method must align with the organization's leave policy. ; Public holidays falling within the month must be deducted from the working day count before calculating daily pay; they are not counted as working days.

Calculation base options are limited to three types: calendar days (actual days in month), working days (excluding weekends and public holidays), or custom days (user-defined per company policy). Calendar days vary by month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 in February). Most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to align with regional labor law requirements. ; Salary component selection is limited to three options: basic salary only, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only.

Changes to salary proration will affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon saving. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving changes to salary proration settings.

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays fall within the calculation month, they must be explicitly subtracted from the working day count. For example, if 2 public holidays occur in a 22-working-day month, daily pay is calculated based on 20 days, not 22 days.

Daily wage calculations vary significantly based on month length when using calendar days method (e.g., January has 31 days while February has 28), which directly impacts final wage amounts for salary proration and leave encashment. Different calculation bases produce different results and must be selected carefully to ensure compliance with company policy and labor law.

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions and then resave the changes for salary proration to take effect properly.

Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) interacts with the Payroll system and directly affects active payroll table transactions; salary proration impacts employee's first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations.
